docs.abstract: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
docs.snippet: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.
docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for the last night of the Republican National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rank the evening on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the night was a disaster for Republicans; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump for the Trump-Pence ticket. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which featured Ivanka Trump and President Trump himself.

headline.main: Republican Convention: Best and Worst Moments From Trump’s Big Night

byline.original: By The New York Times Opinion

docs.abstract: The Black Lives Matter protests and a pandemic may have shifted the political dynamic in favor of progressive candidates of color.
docs.snippet: The Black Lives Matter protests and a pandemic may have shifted the political dynamic in favor of progressive candidates of color.

headline.main: Do New York City Voters Want Another White Mayor?
headline.print_headline: Does New York Want Another White Mayor?

docs.abstract: The records had been sealed for decades, but last month, New York repealed a law keeping them secret after national protests against police brutality.
docs.snippet: The records had been sealed for decades, but last month, New York repealed a law keeping them secret after national protests against police brutality.
docs.lead_paragraph: Over 323,000 accusations of misconduct against current and former New York City police officers were published online on Thursday, a major milestone in a long and contentious political battle to open records of police discipline to public scrutiny.

headline.main: 323,911 Accusations of N.Y.P.D. Misconduct Are Released Online
headline.print_headline: 323,000 Accusations of Misconduct by New York Police Are Released Online

docs.abstract: Wedding vendors are taking to social media to speak out on a host of social and political issues. Some risk losing followers, clients and money as a result. Others feel supported.
docs.snippet: Wedding vendors are taking to social media to speak out on a host of social and political issues. Some risk losing followers, clients and money as a result. Others feel supported.
docs.lead_paragraph: In June, the photographer Shakira Rochelle started taking photographs of Black Lives Matter protesters in her hometown Cincinnati. She shared the images and other supportive B.L.M. content on her personal Instagram account. Shortly, thereafter she received a text from a couple who had hired her to photograph their wedding.

headline.main: Some Wedding Vendors Face Fallout After Speaking Up on Social Issues
headline.print_headline: Speaking Up Possibly Means Losing the Job

docs.abstract: The Black speakers have a job to do: erase history and cloud reality.
docs.snippet: The Black speakers have a job to do: erase history and cloud reality.
docs.lead_paragraph: So far the Republican National Convention isn’t so much presenting a record of America and an administration as it is inventing one.

headline.main: R.N.C. Rewrites Trump’s Racism — and America’s

docs.abstract: The auto plant closed in 1988, turning the Wisconsin city upside down. Now it’s facing an even deeper existential crisis.
docs.snippet: The auto plant closed in 1988, turning the Wisconsin city upside down. Now it’s facing an even deeper existential crisis.
docs.lead_paragraph: KENOSHA, Wis. — Anguished residents wondered if their city would ever recover. The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson came to town and called for justice. An outraged Wisconsin governor vowed to make things right.

headline.main: ‘That Same Feeling’: Painful Memories in Kenosha Come Rushing Back
headline.print_headline: Kenosha, Still Bearing Old Scars, Becomes a Wounded Place Again

docs.abstract: After the coronavirus paused the tours, Williams is gearing up for the U.S. Open, her next opportunity to tie Margaret Court’s Grand Slam singles title record.
docs.snippet: After the coronavirus paused the tours, Williams is gearing up for the U.S. Open, her next opportunity to tie Margaret Court’s Grand Slam singles title record.
docs.lead_paragraph: After her latest long and unexpected break from the sport she once dominated, Serena Williams will return to competition next week at a new tournament, the Top Seed Open in Lexington, Ky.

headline.main: After It All, Serena Williams Still Has No. 24 In Sight
headline.print_headline: Williams Still Has Her Eyes  Set on No. 24

docs.abstract: Our columnists and contributors give their rankings.

docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 1 of the Republican National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rank the evening on a scale of 1 to 10: 1 means the night was a disaster for Republicans; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump for Trump-Pence. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which highlighted Kimberly Guilfoyle, Nikki Haley, Donald Trump Jr., Tim Scott and President Trump himself.

headline.main: Republican Convention: Best and Worst Moments From Night 1

byline.original: By The New York Times Opinion

docs.abstract: Theater for One was built on the idea of face-to-face encounters. Moving it online could have been a disaster, but instead it’s a heartbreaker.
docs.snippet: Theater for One was built on the idea of face-to-face encounters. Moving it online could have been a disaster, but instead it’s a heartbreaker.
docs.lead_paragraph: After my first experience of Theater for One — back in pre-pandemic days, when it meant sharing a small booth with an actor who performed a short play for you — I imagined it as what speed dating would be if you fell in love with everyone you met. Sitting that close to an actor’s face, hearing a story I could not avoid being part of because no one else was there to hear it, I was instantly drawn into the uncanny, enraptured collaboration of theater, with its roots in campfire tales and community bonding and a parent’s hushed voice at bedtime.

headline.main: Review: It’s Just You and Me and the Modem in ‘Here We Are’
headline.print_headline: It’s Way Better Than a Zoom Meeting

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: Thank You for Coming. Take Care. (Play)

docs.abstract: Best known for her series of deconstructed flags, Sonya Clark offers poignant, clearsighted reminders of this country’s legacy of racial violence.
docs.snippet: Best known for her series of deconstructed flags, Sonya Clark offers poignant, clearsighted reminders of this country’s legacy of racial violence.
docs.lead_paragraph: Sonya Clark’s work is unequivocally political: Her 2019 wall hanging “These days. This country. This history.” consists of the remains of an unraveled American flag onto which the unmistakable X of the Confederate battle flag, also in tatters, has been woven, the two flags hopelessly intertwined. She believes the election of Donald Trump added fuel to her fire, and indeed, these days, as we witness the continuing state-sanctioned murder of Black people, her work feels especially relevant. Yet the western Massachusetts-based Clark, 53, isn’t making work for the news cycle. While some political art can, like Trump himself, feel temporary, a product of and for its time, Clark’s goes to the root of longstanding injustices and hypocrisies woven, if not into the actual flag, then into the metaphorical fabric of American culture.
